history.content:
Have you consider late p/np right before you die midway through the semester? No way you need a grade in all three to graduate.
---
This is an excellent combo for destroying yourself. As someone currently spending ~12 hours a day due to 151LB I promise the time commitment is not oversold. 151 and especially 152 has curves insanely skewed high due to the audience interested so proficiency at the level of teaching 61C would be a minimum to consider this schedule. 184 is not as heavy as 151, 162, 164, etc. but has a consistent project workload to factor in. You could be able to do this but you probably wouldn't be planning on doing too much outside of classes if you want to survive. If you still have your late drop trying all 3 and dropping one if necessary should probably be fine. Also, 151 is offered every semester and should have enough external funding (ty Apple), so if you're sure you'll do all 3 eventually I'd pick 152+184.
---
Hey, it's me, the person who asked. I ended up doing 151LB, 152, 184, 3 units of research, and some club leadership positions. So, a retrospective:

This semester has been pretty hard and I've been busy pretty much the whole time, but I honestly didn't find it unmanageably so. I still had time to hang out with friends, going skating, and had enough time between deadlines that I could just spend a whole day each week taking a break. I didn't really have much time to spend on personal projects and I don't think I'd like to have done this while recruiting, but it's totally doable.

151LB has been pretty chill. I think a lot of it is a "knack" sort of thing and so if you end up with a strong intuitive sense for digital design you can really just speed through the projects with little to no debugging. I won't say that everyone has this experience but I know a good number of people who were in a similar boat. I like to joke that 151 is extremely easy so long as you don't make any mistakes, and it's very true because tracking down bugs in huge circuits by staring at waveforms and dumping debug data into registers is certainly not as convenient as stepping through code in gdb. The primary time sink for the class came with the final project. You have long deadlines but you also have a lot of work to do. You're supposed to work on the project over the period of 2+ weeks, but my project partner and I managed to cram the whole thing into a weekend and get checked off the following Monday. It was exhausting but mostly our fault lol. 

152 is a similar story. Labs are pretty time intensive and if you choose to do the "cool" ones (cache reverse engineering, Spectre exploitation, etc.) they can easily take two to three days. If you're less dedicated to doing something cool and are more interested in just surviving, I'm sure going for the other lab options would reduce the workload substantially.

184 was also pretty time heavy but, again, the deadlines are very long and so you have a ton of flexibility with how and when you do things. Lots of debugging and writing, but the flexibility in timing and very easy going grading (there's no AG, it's just screenshots and vibes) made it manageable.

Overall, 151+152 is a fine combo. You'll be busy but if you really like low level stuff and really want to immerse yourself it, there's no better a way. If you don't want to take them concurrently, I would personally recommend 151 and then 152 just because some of the design decisions that come up implicitly in 152 are explained through intuition formed in 151. I'd probably do it again if I had to (and I probably will, next semester is going to be equally spicy LOL) purely because there are just so many good classes here and so little time to take them all.

Have you consider late p/np right before you die midway through the semester? No way you need a grade in all three to graduate.

---

This is an excellent combo for destroying yourself. As someone currently spending ~12 hours a day due to 151LB I promise the time commitment is not oversold. 151 and especially 152 has curves insanely skewed high due to the audience interested so proficiency at the level of teaching 61C would be a minimum to consider this schedule. 184 is not as heavy as 151, 162, 164, etc. but has a consistent project workload to factor in. You could be able to do this but you probably wouldn't be planning on doing too much outside of classes if you want to survive. If you still have your late drop trying all 3 and dropping one if necessary should probably be fine. Also, 151 is offered every semester and should have enough external funding (ty Apple), so if you're sure you'll do all 3 eventually I'd pick 152+184.

children.subject: are you referring to 164 this sem or a past sem?
a possible youtube title: "24 hours spent in Soda Hall!!! You won't believe what I saw!!! Not clickbait!!!!"
If this becomes schedule pls vlog ur life next semester

152 is a pretty unique class, so I'd say to prioritize it among the classes in this schedule, especially if you want a cool architecture gig at Apple or Nvidia. 151 lecture material is very important as well, but writing HDL code (as you do in the FPGA lab) really only requires the first one or two labs to learn, and punishing yourself with the project is likely overkill in general. Perhaps it's possible to P/NP the lab and take the lecture for a grade?

history.content:
I lucked into the three last classes I wanted to take before I graduate and I'm wondering if I'll see the sun at all if I tried taking them all next semester? I've heard 151+FPGA lab is a huge time sink, but I'm a little skeptical because people also said classes like 162 and 164 were time sinks when they weren't really (for me, anyways). I really want to take all of these classes but I'm worried with the way that EECS funding is going that it'll just get harder and harder to take them, so I'm very hesitant to drop any of them.

Good idea? Bad idea? Should I stock pile Sunny D in advance of next semester? Thank you!
history.subject: Will taking EECS151 (FPGA lab), CS152, and CS184 destroy me?
